# Task

You are provided a markdown document `md` with julia language code blocks. Write a function `extract_julia_code` that extracts all the code blocks, removes code fences and joins the code blocks (if there are multiple) together with a newline. Return a String. Do not provide any examples.



# Data

extract_julia_code("""```julia
println("hello world")
```""")

Here is a function that should solve the task:

```julia
function extract_julia_code(md::String)
    # Split the markdown document into lines
    lines = split(md, '\n')

    # Initialize an empty string to store the extracted code
    code = ""

    # Initialize a flag to indicate whether we are inside a Julia code block
    in_julia_block = false

    # Iterate over the lines
    for line in lines
        # If we find a line that starts with "```julia", we are inside a Julia code block
        if startswith(line, "```julia")
            in_julia_block = true
            continue
        end

        # If we find a line that starts with "```", we are no longer inside a Julia code block
        if startswith(line, "```")
            in_julia_block = false
            continue
        end

        # If we are inside a Julia code block, add the line to the code
        if in_julia_block
            code *= line * "\n"
        end
    end

    # Return the extracted code
    return code
end
```

This function works by splitting the markdown document into lines and then iterating over the lines. When it finds a line that starts with "```julia", it sets a flag to indicate that it is inside a Julia code block. When it finds a line that starts with "```", it sets the flag to indicate that it is no longer inside a Julia code block. When it is inside a Julia code block, it adds the line to the code.

Please note that this function assumes that the markdown document is well-formed, i.e., that every code block starts with "```julia" and ends with "```". If the markdown document is not well-formed, this function may not work correctly.
